awd_titl_txt: Improving Science Problem Solving with Adaptive Game-Based Reflection Tools
awd_abstract_narration:
The project is supported by the Education and Human Resources Core Research program, which supports fundamental research in STEM learning and learning environments. Reflection plays a critical role in student learning and encompasses a broad range of cognitive and metacognitive processes enabling students to (1) think critically about their learning processes, (2) integrate new information with prior knowledge, (3) form and adapt learning strategies, (4) view concepts and knowledge from multiple perspectives, (5) generate self-explanations to enrich conceptual understanding, (6) compare learning processes and artifacts to those created by experts and peers, and (7) make metacognitive judgments about knowledge. The National Research Council recently concluded that systematic reflection is essential for deep learning and effective educational practice. This project investigates a suite of theoretically grounded, adaptive game-based reflection tools to scaffold students' cognitive and metacognitive reflection with the overarching objective of improving middle school students' science problem-solving processes. These reflection tools are integrated as part of the existing Crystal Island learning environment.

In studying middle school students' cognitive and metacognitive reflective processes, three key research questions will be addressed: 1) How do embedded and retrospective reflection scaffolds promote improved learning outcomes including science problem-solving skills, science content knowledge, metacognitive awareness, and reflection skills? 2) How can learning analytics be leveraged to extend models of reflection and self-regulated learning for problem solving within game-based learning environments? and 3) How can we create adaptive scaffolding for game-based learning environments that best foster reflection during and following science problem solving? The project builds upon a theoretical framework of self-regulated learning to inform the development of embedded and retrospective scaffold tools, gathering both process data (e.g., log data, eye tracking, think-aloud) and outcome data (e.g., pre- post- learning, transfer, metacognition, self-efficacy) to inform design principles and descriptive models of the role of reflection in students' problem-solving processes. Key project outcomes include an empirically grounded theoretical framework for reflection-enhanced learning and learning analytic techniques that yield predictive models of reflection in science problem solving.

por.por_cntn:
Reflection plays a critical role in student learning and encompasses a broad range of cognitive and metacognitive processes. Reflection enables students to think critically about their learning processes, integrate new information with prior knowledge, form and adapt learning strategies, view concepts and knowledge from multiple perspectives, generate self-explanations to enrich conceptual understanding, compare learning processes and artifacts to those created by experts and peers, and make metacognitive judgments about knowledge. Examining and scaffolding reflective processes poses considerable challenges given the latent nature of student reflection. However, recent developments in technology-rich learning, such as game-based learning environments and learning analytics, enable new approaches to scaffolding students’ reflection and enabling examination of these processes in order to understand how and when students reflect.

The objective of the project was to investigate a suite of theoretically grounded, adaptive game-based reflection tools to scaffold students’ cognitive and metacognitive reflection processes throughout self-regulated learning. Specifically, we leveraged recent advances in game-based learning and learning analytics to investigate novel approaches for scaffolding student reflection. The project had three major thrusts:

1. Engage students in reflection both during and after science problem-solving activities through a series of studies conducted in authentic classroom environments designed to investigate how student reflection influences problem-solving processes, metacognitive awareness, and learning outcomes. We triangulated multimodal data streams to investigate middle school students’ reflective and problem-solving processes as they interacted with the Crystal Island game-based learning environment and reflection scaffolding tools. The studies captured the temporal dynamics of student reflection during problem solving by collecting process data (eye tracking, log files) and reflection responses (embedded prompts, retrospective prompts). We also collected self-reports (metacognitive awareness) and investigated overall learning outcomes (science problem solving, science content knowledge, metacognitive awareness).

2. Create predictive models of student reflection in science problem solving. With the goal of creating models that can be used to both predict student reflection and its relationship to problem solving and learning outcomes, we devised empirically-based models of students’ cognitive and metacognitive reflection processes during science problem solving. To this end, we created models using statistical methods as well as learning analytic techniques with a focus on machine learning methods, including deep neural network and ensemble learning techniques. These models and analyses informed the design of the adaptive scaffolding tools.

3. Enhance student reflection in science problem solving through theoretically grounded, data-driven adaptive reflection scaffolding tools. Informed by models of reflection developed with learning analytics, we devised adaptive reflection scaffolding tools to facilitate reflection during and following science problem solving. We integrated the reflection tools into the Crystal Island game-based learning environment and investigated their impact on student learning outcomes (science content knowledge, science problem-solving skills) and reflection skills. 

The project has made significant contributions to our understanding of how to enhance student learning with adaptive game-based reflection support tools. First, the project saw the formulation of an empirically-based framework for reflection-enhanced learning that addresses both cognitive and metacognitive components of student reflection. By conceptualizing reflection so as to account for self-regulated learning in the context of science problem solving, the project created a rich framework that connects reflection to students’ problem solving and metacognitive processes. Second, the project produced a suite of learning analytic techniques that can be leveraged in predictive models of student reflection during science problem solving. Leveraging advances in multimodal machine learning, the project yielded novel methods for automatically assessing student reflection processes as well as approaches for utilizing students’ written reflection data to inform predictive models of student learning and interest. Third, the project saw the creation of design principles and analytical tools for adaptively scaffolding student reflection processes during game-based learning. This includes the creation of adaptive game-based reflection support tools that are available to the research community and middle school teachers and students. Fourth, the project made significant contributions toward preparation of the future workforce. The project provided engaging technology-rich science learning experiences to hundreds of middle school students, and it provided training and preparation of two postdoctoral scholars and 15 graduate students in computer science, psychology, and design at North Carolina State University and University of Central Florida.
